sp.p: One of them might turn sick, or break a leg, or drink too much at dinner, or some other obstacle occur. [Liddy laughs.] Laugh as you please; I have only one question to ask: can such matters be too prudently managed? answer: no. I shall go, and appoint them both, cause them both to draw up a contract, compare them both, correct them both, and chuse with proper caution one from them both. In the mean while, fair bride! I will beg for a kiss.—

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Fie!

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: [Surprised.] How!

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: [To Liddy.] Must I kiss him?

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: Surely you must.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Well then. [Kisses him, wipes her mouth, and calls after him.] Remember, I tell thee, if the notaries are handsomer than thee, I will then marry them, and not thee.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: Now, dear Gurli, whether would thou like better to be my sister, or my daughter?

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Gurli understands thee not.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: If you marry my brother, then are we sisters.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Right. Gurli rejoices at it.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: But supposing Liddy were to marry thy father, then would Gurli be Liddy's daughter.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: [Looking for some moments doubtfully in her face.] Liddy jokes.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: Who knows but I might perhaps be in earnest, if I could only find out who your father really is? What think you? You may perhaps be able to give me some light.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Hush—Gurli dare not tell.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: Why not? only to me.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Not to my parrot; not to my kitten; not even to the rosebush in my chamber.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: But the cause?

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: My father forbade me.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: Do you hold your father's prohibition so sacred?

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: He never forbade me any thing else in his life— this is the very first time.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: [Embracing her with emotion.] Excellent girl!

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Foolish Liddy!

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: Since you are so very mysterious, I must call my guardian angel to my assistance.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: [Eagerly.] Thy guardian angel! Hast thou one? Ah, Liddy, I am so vexed.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: Be easy; he is the friend of all good men.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Is he so? But is Gurli sufficiently good?

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Gurli is sufficiently good.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Well, what says thy guardian angel?

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: [Seeming to listen to something.] He says that thy father was once Na • ob of Myso • e

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: [Creeping close to Liddy with apparent terror.] Ah, Liddy! he is very right.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: [As before.] He says, Gurli will tell me of the rest.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Says he so! Then Gurli must tell it.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: But without dread, dear girl.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Send him away, then.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: [Making a motion with her hand.] He is gone.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Are you sure?

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: Quite sure.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: But Gurli is a very poor relater; she neither knows how to begin, nor how to end.—My father was Nabob of Mysore: he was just and good: they called him the fountain of justice; for he punished the Derdar, as much as the water-bearer;—with him there was no respect of casts [Weeping.] and yet they have driven him from his native country; and murdered his wives and his children, and me they have suffered to live.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: Who drove him out, and for what reason?

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p:
See, my father has two brothers, a couple of odious ugly men.—Ha, ha, ha! the one squints, and has a nose so long—and the other a head like a hollowed Kurbis, into which our Jugglers put their snakes—ha, ha, ha! well, his head was full of snakes too. The wicked man!—Liddy, there are sad wicked men in the world. [Clenching her fist, and stamping with her foot.] If I had him here, I would fix these nails firmly enough in his bristly locks.—He wished also to be Nabob of Mysore; and the other with the long nose too. Well, they plotted a sad villainy together, and got all the Nairs upon their side, and in one night they attacked our house. Ah! dear Liddy, what a fright; and a shrieking, and a wailing, and a terrible alarm. Ah! I shudder still when I think of that night. I sprung out of bed, and was quite out of my wits—Ha, ha, ha! my gold necklace I tied about my arm, and wrapt my apron about my head. [Weeping.] My poor father was obliged to fly through thick and thin in the dark night, and Gurli fled with him.
Gurli sat in a palanquin; old Musaffery assisted to carry it; [Laughing.] and because it was a labour he had not been used to, he was falling every moment into the mire. At length we came to the sea shore. My father was calm and gloomy, and spoke not a word. [Weeping] Gurli wept sadly for her poor mother, and for her poor brothers and sisters. We went on board an English ship; the Captain was a foolish merry fellow; [Laughing.] he made Gurli laugh very much. We sailed many days through ihe sea, and many weeks after one another; at last Gurli began to tire; and at last, and at last we came hither.—Now I have told you all.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: I thank you, and will immediately return your confidence; but you have not yet answered my first question • whether you had rather be my sister or my daughter?

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Well, Gurli would rather be thy sister.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Because Gurli had a mother already—a good, good mother! Gurli cannot wish to have a better one. But Gurli never yet had a sister.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: Well Gurli, we will live together as sisters. I am to marry your father.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: No, Liddy, jest not with Gurli.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: I do not jest. He left me just now; and God was the witness of our mutual engagement.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Indeed! ha, ha, ha! [Leaping about, snapping her fingers, and singing to it in a tune of her own.] That is charming! that is charming! how I rejoice! Liddy, I must kiss thee! [Takes hold of her head with both hands, and gives her a • ea • ty smack.]

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: Happy girl! teach me to continue a child like thee.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Does then my father know already, that thou art willing to marry him?

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: [Smiling.] Certainly he knows.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: What a pity! I wish he had not yet known it. Gurli would have been so happy to have told him.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: But he knows not yet, that you are to marry my brother.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Well, he will know that in time enough.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: [As soon as she perceives him, with a cry of surprise and joy.] Ah, Jack! where is your master?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: [Always in a frank blunt manner.] We have just now anchored in the harbour.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: [Beside herself.] Gurli! Gurli! Rejoice with me! Brother Robert is come! Father! Mother! Brother Robert is come! Runs out.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: [Jumping about.] Charming! Charming! Brother Robert is come! Hark you! Who is Brother Robert?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Mr. Robert and Miss Liddy were both taken from one store-house—he is her brother.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: He is her brother! Charming; and Liddy is so very glad! and Gurli so glad too, whenever she sees Liddy glad. Come hither, thou dirty man; I must give thee a kiss for thy good news. [Kisses the astonished Boatswain, turns about, and skips into her own chamber, crying out] Brother Robert is come! Brother Robert is come! Exit.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: I'll be damn'd, if she is not wrong in the upper works! She seems not to be very deeply laden with understanding. All these smooth female faces, I value as little as a rotten rope. I wish we were at sea again. What the devil are we to do here among these cursed land rats! The old fellow is well enough—only his timbers are a little decayed. God knows how long he may be able to drive before the wind. As for the mother, she is a hurricane; never blows from one quarter, but veers about to every point in the compass.

div.head: SCENE IX.
div.stage: Sir JOHN, rolled in upon his Chair by LIDDY and JACK.

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.p: Welcome ashore! old faithful Jack.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: God bless you, Sir! how goes it?

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.p: Not very well, dear Jack.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Ay, ay, the old Timber begins to crack. Your bowsprit, I see, is the worse for the wear.

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.p: But for this once, joy has got the better of pain. Where is my son?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: He is sailing up after me; I think he must be here before one could reckon the cross-beams upon the mainmast.

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.p: Well, honest fellow, tell me, in the mean while somewhat about your voyage? I will order them afterwards, to bring up for yourself and your comrades, a cask of strong beer.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Thank you Sir. We weighed anchor in fine weather, and a fair south south east wind. It shifted about once or twice, and yet (praised be God for it) we never got out of deep water.

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.p: But you have not defied wind and waves to no purpose? Have you brought home any thing for yourselves? Are your bags well filled?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Lord! No: Our bags are so empty, that one might use them instead of pendants.

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.p: Alas! Alas! And yet you took a fine cargo with you?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: So I think; a fine cargo! We might easily have made five thoasand pounds of it, but I'll be damn'd if there is a shilling of it in our pockets.

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.p: Impossible! Could Robert have squandered it all away again, unmindful of the poverty of his old father?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p:
Wrong not your son, sir, a nobler fellow never broke biscuit, that I'll maintain. You must know, that as we were on our return, and steering about two hundred
leagues to the westward of the Canary Island • early one morning, we perceived at a distance somethi ••
〈◊〉 the sea, which we were not able to make out. Soon a •
〈◊〉 we heard a couple of guns fired, and saw a piece of sailcloth flying. Holla, cried the Captain, these must certainly be signals of distress; and by my poor soul, so they were. We took in the top ••• , and lay till the thing came nearer. I am but a rough fellow, sir [Wiping his eyes.] but I'll be damn'd if my upper bowsprit is not always wet with spray-water, whenever I think of it. •
• mall rotten boat, and twenty-three famished men in it, who had not, for five whole days, had one morsel of biscuit between their teeth. Their ship had taken fir •
〈◊〉 the middle of the sea; they had with much labour and difficulty escaped into the boat, and were now driving at the mercy of the wind. Twenty-four hours longer, and all would have been over with the poor devils. The Captain, a fine fellow of a Dutchman, had lost every thing but his life and the honor of a sailor▪ and at home sat his young wife, and three small children, who had not a morsel to put into their mouths. Whenever he spoke of them, he pumped clear water from both his eyes. This my master could not stand. Comrade, said he to him, I have neither wife nor child, here are five thousand pounds, take the purse, and God bless you; and soon after he put him ashore along with his people at the first port.

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.p: Did he so? Then, for that, God will bless him: and I am glad that he has brought home nothing, and will willingly divide with him my last morsel.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: Oh, my generous, my noble brother! Did I not always tell you, father, that Robert would be the pride of your old age.

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.p: The pride and joy of my old age!

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: Ah! Here he is!

div.head: SCENE X.
div.stage: ROBERT, Sir JOHN, LIDDY, and JACK.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: [Pressing her to his breast.] My good Liddy.

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.p: [Endeavouring to move forward with 〈◊〉 chair.] Damn this gout! Help me Jack. Heyday! Rascal! Your father is here too.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: [Embracing him rather roughly.] Dearest father.

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.p: Ah, woe! You Jackanapes, don't you know I have the gout? Now, now, it is over again; come, come, let this kiss, and this squeeze, be the tokens of my joy at your arrival; and this blessing [Laying his hand upon him.] the recompence of your generous action.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: What action, father?

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: Oh! we know all already.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: [Looking displeased at Jack.] Has Jack been letting his tongue loose again, and blabbing old wives stories?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: My God! Sir, be not offended; my mouth only got a- • loat.

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.p: In with ye! in with ye! jolly dogs. Your mother is within in her chamber, and at prayers. But she will surely look upon you kindly for once. [Moving forward with his chair.] Come, come, help the poor old sinner forwards.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: I will take post myself in the rear. [He pushes forwards.] Exeunt all there.

sp.speaker: LIDDY
sp.p:
How is it with me? Ah, my resolution is wonderful! I had not the courage to enquire after him. Is he come back▪ or, have they left him in the West-Indies? or, is he sick▪ or, dead? Alas! what matters it to me! What business
have I to ask after him? Fate seems desirous to put me to the trial, whether I am truly in earnest, in sacrificing the first attachment of my heart to filial duty, and filial love. It appeared so easy to me; but, alas! it is not so easy as I thought. Well, but the victory is the more glorious. But I may still continue his friend. I may still know what has become of him. The wish surely is not criminal. When Jack comes out I will ask at him.

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: [Running to Liddy, and seizing her hand.] Here she is! here she is! Ah! dear Miss! Fazir is here again, and is so happy, so happy; go • d, dear Miss, Fazir cannot express 〈…〉 words, nearly so well as he would wish to do. Have 〈◊〉 been always well? have you been always cheerful? have you thought sometimes on poor Fazir?

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: [In great confusion.] Very often—but not to-day.

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: Well did my good angel know it, and blew with all his might upon our sails—whizz, whizz! and we were here; and now dear Liddy, you must think upon me. But you are not glad to see me again—you should not be quite so glad as I am, but yet a little, a very little, since I am so fond of you.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: [With emotion giving him her hand.] Indeed I am glad.

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p:
[Kissing her hand with ardour.] I deserve surely, that you should like me a little; for I have ever and ever thought so much upon you; and thought upon nothing—nothing but you. When the sun arose out of the sea▪ then I stretched out my arms, and prayed—I intended t •
• ray for myself, but I soon found that I was praying for Liddy. When the sea was calm and smooth as glass, then I sought Liddy's image in it—and found it too—for I found it every where
that I sought it—ah! and I found it often without seeking for it.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: [Turns about, and wipes away a tear from her eyes.] Image of my poor sick father, support me in this hour of trial!

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: And when at last the coast of England lay in blue prospe • t before us—ah! Liddy, had you then seen the foolish Fazir, how happy he was—it was yesterday evening. The whole night I could not do any thing but jump about upon the deck, and when morning dawned, there came a bird, flying from the land, and perched upon our mast; I called to it; I whistled to it, and could have kissed it! perhaps, thought I, Liddy • as gone a walking yesterday, and this bird has been singing her a song.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: [Aside.] No, I must put • n end to this, it grows too much for my poor heart. [With hesitation.] Don't you know, Fazir—that I am a bride.

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p:
[In great surprise, answers with a long] So! [A long pause—Liddy holds down her eyes—Fazir str •
〈◊〉 out his hand to her very mournful.] Farewel, dear Miss.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: Where are you going?

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: I—I am going—upon the sea—into the sea—farewel, dear Miss— [He holds her hand: she is silent: a pause.] Yes, I will go—but I cannot—indeed I cannot— [Another pause.] Is Miss Liddy really a bride?

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: Really.

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: And will the good Liddy be happy?

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: She hopes so.

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: Well, Fazir will not be happy; but what matters that, if Liddy be happy? May I ask who is the man that has gained Liddy's heart? No, no, I wish not to know him; I hate no body; he has not done me any harm. Ah! yes, he has done me a great deal of harm.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: [Much affected.] Continue my friend.

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p:
Yes, dear Miss, Fazir would suffer death for your sake.—Ah! it is only about six weeks ago, that we had a severe storm; I was very vexed at the thoughts of dying;
for I wanted to see Liddy again.—I was a fool to be afraid of death; it would have been better if I had not seen Liddy again.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: Won't you visit my father and mother?

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: Oh yes, Miss, if you command it.—I will do every thing that you command.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: [Seizing his hand.] Come, come, it is good for neither of us to remain here together, and talk about matters which cannot be altered. [She is about to lead him out.]

div.head: SCENE XIII.
div.stage: Lady SMITH, ROBERT, JACK, FAZIR, and LIDDY.

sp.speaker: L. Smith.
sp.p: But, my son, this was not pretty of you, after gaining your property so hardly, so want only to squander it away.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: I ask your pardon, dear mother, it was the prettiest thing I ever did in my life.

sp.speaker: L. Smith.
sp.p: Which way can you now do proper honor to your rank?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: By my sentiments.

sp.speaker: L. Smith.
sp.p: Right, my son, that phrase was noble: [perceiving Fazir.] Bon jour, Monsieur Fazir; I am charmed to see you in good health: [continuing her speech to Robert] externals, however, must not be neglected; the sun indeed is always the same sun, though he conceals himself behind a veil of clouds; but he then only dazzles the eye with blindness, when he appears decorated with all his b • ams. What think you of that allegory?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Very pretty, dear mother; but I am no sun, and wish not to blind any body.

sp.speaker: L. Smith.
sp.p:
I could have wished at least, that you had condescended to borrow some warmth from his beams. You are not ignorant that this house is now under the dominion
of want, and that we waited with anxiety for your fortunate return.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: [Shrugging up his shoulders.] My God! I am sorry for that; but had I at that moment been master of a million, the last shilling would have escaped my pocket.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: Dear mother, our poverty will quickly disappear, if you do not refuse me your consent and your blessing.

sp.speaker: L. Smith.
sp.p: Blessings as many as you will; but my consent —to what? If it is only compatible with honor.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: I think it is. Our tenant has solicited my hand.

sp.speaker: L. Smith.
sp.p: [In a lofty satirical tone.] So?

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: He is a generous man.

sp.speaker: L. Smith.
sp.p: So?

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: Rich.

sp.speaker: L. Smith.
sp.p: So?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: [Holding out his hand to Liddy.] I wish you joy with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: [With a sigh.] And I too, dear Miss.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: [With a scrape.] May you always have fair weather, and a good wind to your voyage.

sp.speaker: L. Smith.
sp.p: Not so very hastily, I pray you.—Liddy, you. know my sentiments.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: I know them; but if I can convince you, dear mother, that his birth is unexceptionable—

sp.speaker: L. Smith.
sp.p: That would give quite another turn to the matter.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: You may soon hear it from his own mouth; he promised to pay his respects to you in a few minutes.

sp.speaker: L. Smith.
sp.p: Did he so? Then we must prepare ourselves a little for his reception.—Quick, Liddy, lest he catch us in the anti-chamber—but I tell you this: your mother is a connoisseur—by his mode of conducting himself, in so delicate an affair, I shall immediately distinguish the man of quality. Follow me. Exit with Liddy.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: She did not leave me any time to ask my sister the name of her bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: He need not be ashamed of showing his flag.

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: He must be a good man since he is beloved by Liddy.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: My brother Samuel too is to venture his cautious neck in the matrimonial noose.—Hem, must I then sail through the world alone? what think you Jack?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: I think, Sir, you should let marriage alone.—He that casts anchor on a wife, lies on a damn'd bad bottom, and cannot, at last, shift his cable, even although it should cost him his life. Let no man, setting out on the voyage of life, venture to take a wife aboard; else he will founder in ihe first storm.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Do you think so too, Fazir?

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: I think it is best to die.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: To die! Are you mad?—Jack, what is it that vexes our young comrade?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: I think, he has taken too heavy a cargo of love aboard.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Has he hit it, Fazir?

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: Good Robert, yes, I am in love.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: What the devil! we have scarcely been two hours ashore—you catch fire damned quickly.

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: Oh! I was in love before we sailed.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: And never told me a syllable about it.

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: My love was so silent and secret, that you would not have understood me.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Hark you, my dear, that was stupid. When frequently in the calm • weather, we lay upon the deck in the warm sunshine, and the ship stood as if nailed to one spot; then would have been the time to tell me how the storm raged in your heart. Or how, has not Robert deserved your confidence? Am I not the only person that is acquainted with the secret of your birth? and have I betrayed you?

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: [Falling upon his neck.] Forgive me, brother: it is not ingratitude: truly it is not: thou hast delivered me from death, and at the risk of thy own life, rescued me from the cruelty of my pursuers. I will never forget it—indeed I am not ungrateful.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Very well, very well: it was not my intention to extort acknowledgments from you: the confidence of friendship is all that I require. But who is this girl of your's?

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: My girl! alas, no! The girl that I love—her name is—Liddy.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Liddy! what the devil! my sister?

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: Yes, it is she.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p:
Poor youth: now I understand for what reason you wished to die—you had been transported with the idea of seeing her again, and now you find she is a bride—fie, this is a bad business. I see that the matrimonial wind is not favorable to either of us—let us then cruise about a while longer, and instead of love, take friendship for our compass—you shall be my foremast, and Jack here my mizenmast. I hope yet to weather m • a rough blast in your company; but if you were to fo •
〈◊〉 me, all my tackle would immediately be useless.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: If ever I forsake you, may I be keelhauled.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: [To Fazir.] Courage, brave youth—cleanse your bowsprit from spray-water, and hoist up all your resolution —come, comrades. The weather has turned out stormy here at home; we will dine together at the next tavern, and empty our glasses to Liddy's health.

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: Yes, yes, to Liddy's health—come.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: The two Lawyers, Mr. STRUSSEL and Mr. STAFF, complimenting one another at the door.

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: Unexpected pleasure!

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Agreeable surprise!

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: To meet Mr. Staff in my way!

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: To find Mr. Strussel here!

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: Please to walk in.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Cannot do it.

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: Must do it, must do it.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: I am not so impolite. I know very well, that the first place among the learned in law belongs to my worthy friend, Mr. Strussel.

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p:
Nonsense! nonsense! But wherefore any ceremony between two such cordial friends?
Hauls him in v • in him.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p:
Yes, indeed, cordial friends! [They sha •
• me another's hands, and both aside at the same time say] Devil ••• ch you!

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p:
How goes all at home? All well I hop •
▪

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: At your service. Whenever I come home, they ask me whether I have not seen my excellent friend, Mr. Strussel? And how goes it with your family? How is Jammey my little godson?

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: A funney rogue. I am preaching to him daily, that he should form himself entirely after the model of his excellent godfather, Mr. Staff. [Both making bows to each other —Strussel aside.] What an ass!

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: [Aside.] What an ox!

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: [Aside.] What wants he here?

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: [Aside.] What the devil brings him hither?

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: My dear colleague has probably business here.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Well guessed: and my worthy colleague may perhaps be in the same predicament.

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: At your service. May one be so bold as to ask what sort of business?

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: A trifle—only a marriage contract.

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: [Whose choler begins to rise.] So! a marriage contract! ay, ay! a mere trifle! I am here on the same account.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Ay, ay! Then there is a blessing fallen on this house: Mr. Samuel Smith, surveyor of the customs, appointed me to come hither.

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: Ay, ay! the same gentleman sent for me.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Ay, ay! curious enough; and scarcely credible.

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: [In a passion.] Credible or not credible, it is yet true, Mr. Staff.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: You must be mistaken, Mr. Colleague.

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: I am never mistaken, Mr. Colleague, and once for all, Mr. Staff, you are a person without conscience, who lays himself out for nothing else but to snatch away the bread from his neighbour's mouth.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: How, Colleague, have you the boldness?

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: Yes, Colleague, I have the boldness.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: You will repent of this, Colleague.

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: We shall see that just now, Colleague.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: The best thing you can do, Colleague, is to return to the place from which you came.

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: And the best thing you can do, is to go to the devil.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Now I must insist upon seeing you home.

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: I shall be ashamed to walk the streets with you.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: People might indeed wonder to see you once more in honest company—

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: I am always in honest company, unless when I am in your's.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Sir, you grow impertinent—

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: And you are so already.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: If you do not quickly talk in a softer tone, I will let you feel the weight of my fist.

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: So much the better—come away; it is long since I wished for one boxing bout with such a sad dog as you.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Excellent! Though it will not be much honor to tread under foot such a hog as you. [Both of them throw off their coats and wigs, and put themselves in the attitude of boxers.]

sp.speaker: Tidewaiter.
sp.p: [Running instantly betwixt them.] How! how! what the devil! Gentlemen, I believe you mean, in all haste, to have a little bout at boxing.

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: [Pointing to Staff.] You are the guardian angel of that fellow.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: [Pointing to Strussel.] He is obliged to you for his life. [They put on their coats and wigs again.]

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: But we shall meet again, Mr. Staff.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Yes, yes, we shall meet, Mr. Strussel.

sp.speaker: Tidewaiter.
sp.p: Will ye not have the goodness to tell me how it came into your heads here, to fall ſoul of each other with all precipitation?

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: [Crying as loud as he can bawl.] He asserts, that Mr. Samuel Smith sent for him on account of a marriage contract, which he committed to me alone to make out, with all its necessary points and clauses.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: [In the same tone.] He is so audacious as to assert, that his unpractised quill was intrusted with a contract, the heads of which, but a few hours ago, Mr. Samuel Smith dictated to me.

sp.speaker: Tidewaiter.
sp.p: [Stopping both his ears.] Have mercy, gentlemen, have mercy upon me: the drum of any ears must infallibly crack.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: SAMUEL, STAFF, STRUSSEL, and the TIDEWAITER.
div.p: [Both Lawyers rushing upon Samuel.] Here is the contract, sir.

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: Cautiously, gentlemen! cautiously! you had almost run me down.

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: Am I not here by your command?

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: Yes, indeed.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Did you not appoint me to come hither?

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: Yes, indeed.

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: Did you not order me to make a marriage-contract for you?

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: Yes, indeed.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Was not I to bring a marriage-contract for you?

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: Yes, indeed.

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Staff.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Strussel.

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: But, may I ask, Sir, why you have thought proper to trouble two of the most eminent lawyers in a matter, in which, at all events, even half a one would have been sufficient?

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: Why! might not one of you have met with an accident, which might have prevented his appearing at the time appointed?

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Rashly done, Sir, rashly done! By this means you had well nigh been the cause of a very bloody combat betwixt me and my worthy colleague, Mr. Strussel.

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: Very imprudent in you, Sir, thus, for nothing, or less than nothing, to make a couple of old cordial friends fall to logger heads with one another.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: If we did not love one another so dearly.

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: And esteem one another so highly. [Both holding out their hands.] Ha, ha, ha! we are the old thing again.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Our friendship is as firm as a rock.

sp.speaker: Tidewaiter.
sp.p: Quickly provoked, and speedily reconciled. Such precipitation is praise-worthy.

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: Where are the contracts?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: I intreat ye to read slowly and distinctly.

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: Read, Mr. Staff.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: I beg you would read, Mr. Strussel.

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: God forbid. I know my duty.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: And I know mine.

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: Wherefore so much ceremony? A couple of eminent men like us, must make out a marriage-contract in the same way, it is then the same thing which of us reads.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Quite the same.

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: Well, if you absolutely command me to do it. [Takes out his spectacles and reads.] "Be it known hereby, to all to whom the knowledge may be necessary."

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p:
[Consulting his own manuscript.] With your leave,
Colleague, it ought to be: "Be it known hereby to all whom it may concern."

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: [In a rage.] Why so, Colleague?

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Because it is possible that a case may occur, in which the knowledge may be necessary to many, who yet may not have any concern to know. Nobody, on the contrary, can be concerned to know, to whom that knowledge will not be necessary.

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: A very nice distinction.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: [In a passion.] Not indeed for the brain of every one.

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: You are an ignoramus, Mr. Colleague.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: How! what! I an ignoramus? If I were to divide my learning among ninety-nine men, they would all be as learned as Mr. Strussel.

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: Ay, provided they were so before-hand.

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: Pardon me, Mr. Strussel, I think Mr. Staff is right.

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: How! Is he right?

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: Prudence always commands us to chuse those expressions which are the most appropriated.

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: You are a fool with your prudence.

sp.speaker: Staff, Samuel, and the Tidewaiter.
sp.p: [All at once.] A fool! a fool! You rude fellow—pack off—march clown stairs.— [All three fall upon him together, and push him towards the door.]

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: [While he is turned out.] And I say it ought to be: "Be it known hereby, to all to whom the knowledge may be necessary."

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Staff, we shall now be in quiet, and may examine the contract with proper caution. Do you read.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: [Putting on his spectacles and reading.] "Be it known hereby, to all whom it may concern."

sp.speaker: Strussel.
sp.p: [Shewing his head at the door.] "To all to whom the knowledge may be necessary."

sp.speaker: Tidewaiter.
sp.p: [Driving him off.] Begone, begone; off, off, off.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: No, I cannot endure it any longer. May I ask, Sir, what evil spirits have been amusing themselves before my door.

sp.speaker: Tidewaiter.
sp.p: We have just now turned him out with the greatest precipitation.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: Whom? the evil spirit!

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Yes, indeed, an evil spirit! a demon! a cacodemon— a spiritus infernalis—

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: We are assembled here, Sir, to deliberate together concerning the happiness of your daughter.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: What concern have you with my daughter's happiness?

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: Answer: a great deal: Miss Gurli felt that she stood in need of a prudent companion, who weighed his words, and measured his steps, along the slippery path of this life. Her rational, laudable, and unexceptionable choice fell upon me; and now, the only question that remains is, whether Gurli's father has any objection to make to our union? Answer.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: [Stares at him, shakes his head, then turns about, opens the door of his chamber, and calls] Gurli.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: [Within.] Father?

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: Come forth.

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: GURLI, KABERDAR, SAMUEL, STAFF, and TIDEWAITER.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: What would'st thou, father? [Perceiving the Lawyer.] Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: Be serious, Gurli.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: [Striking his cheek.] What does my father command?

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: [Pointing to Samuel.] Art Ihou willing to marry that man?

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: I promised it to Liddy.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: Dost thou love him?

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: I love Liddy.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: But it is he, not Liddy, who it to be thy husband.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: But he is Liddy's brother.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: [Aside.] That is his greatest merit.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: And he is always to stay where thou stayest, father —Gurli will never forsake thee—and Liddy is to stay there too. Is it not true, foolish Samuel?

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: Answer: yes.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: Thou hop'st then to be happy with him.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Not with him alone, but with him, with thee, and with Liddy.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: Well, God bless ye! I have nothing to object against it. [He embraces his daughter, and then Samuel, who recieves it with great solemnity.] Sir, you will at once be my son and my brother.

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: Double honor—double pleasure—double satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: Yes, if it should doubly succeed.

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: No doubt—Will you please now to hear the contract read over!

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: I am quite indifferent; as there is but one article in which I can have any concern: the article of the dowry.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Here we have left room for it. Showing him the paper.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: So much, indeed, that one might insert in it the title of a large kingdom, with all the provinces, which it either possesses or does not possess. Did you think, Sir, that I was so very rich?

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: I thought you was very rich, and very generous.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p:
Indeed! then I must be a wonderful man; for wealth and generosity I have never yet found together. Every virtue may however degenerate; and so likewise may generosity. You know, Sir, that I am on the eve of taking another wife to myself, and it is not impossible that
a dozen of children may hereafter lay claim to my paternal generosity.

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: [Perplexed.] Ay, ay!

sp.speaker: Tidewaiter.
sp.p: Ay, ay!

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Umph, umph!

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: How much do you then reckon necessary to enable you and my daughter to live neither in indigence, nor in superfluity: neither penuriously, nor yet with prodigality.

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: Well then, in such cases, one had better reckon too much than too little.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: What if we were to strike the medium, and fix upon a sum often thousand pounds?

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: [In a tone of satisfaction.] Ah, we should not suffer them to rust.

sp.speaker: Tidewaiter.
sp.p: [In a whisper to Samuel.] Get the matter concluded quickly.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Let us insert the payment of that sum in this empty space.

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: Moreover, I flatter myself with a favorable answer to the following query: If Heaven should bless our union with children—

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Hark you, shall we then have children?

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: I hope so.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Then will Gurli laugh terribly.—Gurli never yet had any children.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Hora ruit: that is, the precious time is passing away. May it please you to impart to this contract, by means of the subscription of the contracting parties, the proper formality, steadfastness, and indissolubility?

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: Well said. Go, my dear Tidewaiter, and summon hither my family—they must all of them be present at this solemnity.— [Exit Tidewaiter.] —Will you have the goodness to answer me one question more: The fruits which may be expected from this union, in what religion are they to be educated? answer.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: [With some warmth.] Bring you them up to be honest men, and make what else of them you please.

div.head: SCENE VI.
div.stage: Sir JOHN, Lady SMITH, LIDDY, KABERDAR, GURLI, SAMUEL, STAFF, and TIDEWAITER.

sp.speaker: Tidewaiter.
sp.p: They come! they come!

sp.speaker: L. Smith.
sp.p: [After making a careless curtsey to the company, walks hastily up to her son.] My son, you behold your mother in despair: will you then be so barbarous as to graft crab-apples upon a peach-tree?

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: [Taking her aside.] No rose without thorns. They begin a secret conversation.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: [To Liddy.] Well, sweet sister, art thou satisfied with Gurli?

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: Gurli is a good girl.

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.p: [To Kaberdar.] Sir, you have confounded an old man, and made him doubt the philosophy of his whole life. Had any one told me to go out to the highway, where so many thousands pass every day, and that there I should find a treasure, truly I would sooner have believed it, than that I could have found a rich man who generously wishes to be allied to a family in reduced circumstances, without rank or fortune—

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, what a country is your Europe, if you mean seriously what you now say! The warm sun with us, hatches no such folly.

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.p: Your hand, Sir. It is now so long since I have squeezed the hand of an honest man.— You are my physician—you have poured new life and vigour into the veins of an old man.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: I do nothing gratis— my recompense is a pearl: [Looking tenderly at Liddy.] such as neither Ceylon, nor Arabia Felix, nor the Pearl Islands themselves contain. Talks apart with Liddy.

sp.speaker: Tidewaiter.
sp.p: [To Staff.] All is well hitherto; but matters like these ought to be quickly and speedily concluded.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p:
Yes, indeed; but before all, the due formalities ought to be observed.—Love, gratitude, and felicity, and
all such nonsense as that, will come of itself, after matters are concluded.

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: But, dear mother, although you were to cause a ragout to be made of your genealogical tree, we must still go every night hungry to bed.

sp.speaker: L. Smith.
sp.p: Fie, fie, my son, I give thee up; for I see that the noble maternal milk, which I instilled into thee, was lavished in vain.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: [Slipping behind them, and pushing her head in betwixt them.] What are you chattering about so secretly together?

sp.speaker: L. Smith.
sp.p: A pretty behaviour! I shall never adventure to carry this creature into a brilliant circle.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: [With some sensibility.] I hope, Madam, she will hereafter cut a better figure, in the domestic circle of her children.

sp.speaker: L. Smith.
sp.p: [Scornfully.] A good mother of a family has indeed some merit.

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.p: That she has, and in every station— of which our queen is an illustrious example.

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: We are prattling away the precious time.

sp.speaker: Tidewaiter.
sp.p: Yes, indeed— yes, indeed.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Well then, be quick.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: The contract is ready for subscription.

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: Come then, here is pen and ink: [Laying the paper right.] on this little space Miss Gurli will write her name.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Dost thou think, foolish man, that Gurli has not learned to write? Give it me here— Taking the pen.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: [With anxiety.] Yet once more, my daughter, bethink thyself well: the happiness of thy whole future life hangs upon one single word. When once thou hast written, thy promise is irrevocable.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Dear father, Gurli will write at all events— see, only, how Liddy looks at me so mournfully, and the old man there seems also to wish it. I like the old man, he looks so honest.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p:
In God's name, it is thy free will—thy father's
blessing— and, if God will, some good angel be with thee. Gurli about to write.

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: Stop, fair Gurli, stop one moment. I have turned at once so uneasy.— Is there then nothing omitted? no rule of prudence? no clause of consequence?

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Nothing, nothing. Mr. Staff has taken care of every thing.

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.p: My son, the coolness of your behaviour betrays very little tender feeling.

sp.speaker: L. Smith.
sp.p: Perhaps it may be the spirits of your ancestors whispering to you at this decisive moment.

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: Not so, my dear mother.— [To Kaberdar.] The ten thousand pounds, Sir, which you was so good as to make mention of, will they be paid directly after the wedding?

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: [With great coldness.] On the wedding day, Sir.

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: [To Gurli.] Well, write now, fair Gurli.— [Gurli about to write.] But yet, hold one moment.— I really find myself in an uncommon situation. One cannot go too cautiously to work.— One question more, Sir: will the ten thousand pounds be paid in bank-notes, or in hard cash? answer.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: [Displeased.] As you please, Sir; as you chuse yourself.

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: In hard cash, then, if it is wholly the same to you.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: Now you may write.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: [About to write.] Foolish man! thou art so tiresome.

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: Stop, stop, for one moment.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: Brother, you are insufferable.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: [To Liddy.] You are his guardian angel.

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: There still remains one reasonable and important question to determine. If the father of my fair Gurli should decease, and leave behind him no other heirs of his body, then—

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: Then Gurli will be the heiress of my whole fortune.

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p:
[In a very friendly tone.] Your most obedient, humble servant— all doubts are removed, Mr. Samuel Smith
now embraces boldly, and courageously, a hasty resolution —write Gurli.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Well, I will write; but if thou criest "stop," once more, I will throw the pen and ink at your head.

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.p: And very deservedly.

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: Write, write. [While Gurli dips her pen into the ink-horn, to sign her name, Enter]

div.head: SCENE VII.
div.stage: ROBERT, JACK, SIR JOHN, LADY SMITH, LIDDY, KABERDAR, GURLI, SAMUEL, STAFF, and TIDEWAITER.
[Gurli immediately drops the pen, and stands gaping on Robert.]

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: The devil and the Dutch! what a large company!

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: And plenty of the sivens— turn about your ship, sir.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: You fool, I am no woman-hater.

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: You come, just in time, brother, to sign your name, as witness to my contract of marriage.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: With all my heart—much happiness to your voyage.

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.p: Robert, here is an honest man, who will in future make a part of our family.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: I am glad of it: Sir, I am no man for compliments— your hand, Sir [Shakes Kaberdar by the hand.] I am your servant; and if it be true that you are an honest man, I am your friend.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: Friendship is the blossom of a moment, but the fruit of time.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: True! very true! what ripens before its time, is blown down by the first wind.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: [To Liddy with eagerness.] Who is that man?

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: That is brother Robert.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Brother Robert! ay—I like brother Robert.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Is this the bride? I am happy of your acquaintance: [going up to her] favor me with a kiss.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Ten, if you will. [Kisses him.]

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: Now, Miss, I beg you will write.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: The formalities have been drawn into length.

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: [Urging Gurli.] Will you be pleased▪ [Gurli shakes her head.]

sp.speaker: L. Smith.
sp.p: [Half aside.] These are the most tedious espousals, that ever I was a witness of.—

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: [To Liddy.] Hark you, now Liddy, I like brother Robert better than brother Samuel.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: Foolish girl.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: Gurli, thou art childish.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Be not angry, dear father, Gurli has her free will.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: That she has.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Well, Liddy, is it the same to thee, whether Gurli marries thy brother Samuel, or thy brother Robert?

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: [Smiling.] The same to me, dear Gurli; but not to Samuel.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Ah! what! the foolish man! who will ask his leave? [Goes up to Robert.] Dear brother Robert, wilt thou be so good as to marry Gurli?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: [Much astonished.] How! what!

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: An uncommon casus.

sp.speaker: L. Smith.
sp.p: It is unique.

sp.speaker: Tiderwaiter.
sp.p: Inconceivably rapid.

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: I am petrified.

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.p: [Smiling to Kaberdar.] One of my sons is the happy man, and it is equal to me which.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: [Significantly.] To me it is not equal.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Well, thou dost not give me any answer.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: What the devil can I answer?

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Don't you like me?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Oh, yes!

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Well, I like thee. Thou art such a merry man, that I am fond of looking at thee. Thine eyes speak so well, that one wishes always to answer, although they know not what.—Well?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Miss, I am not acquainted with you: I see you to-day for the first time in my life.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Yes, indeed, and I thee too. But Gurli would wish to see thee for ever.
At my risk, brother.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Damn me, if the girl is not charming! but I cannot deceive you, Miss—I am a poor devil, and have nothing but a ship of 1200 tons burden; with which I must scour the wide ocean to-morrow, and perhaps go to the bottom next day.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Thou must not go to sea, thou must stay at home with Gurli.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: And starve with Gurli.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: Sir, this incident is singular of its kind; and must naturally surprize you very much. She is my daughter; a good girl; a child of nature; her dowry is ten thousand pounds sterling.—I have nothing farther to say on the subject.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Sir, I care as much for ten thousand pounds, as I do for a rotten plank; and I should not be willing to suffer myself to be crammed to death by my wife.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Fool, I will feed thee, and not cram thee.—Marry me, however, and thou shalt not repent it. [Stroking his cheeks.] I will be so fond of thee, so fond—

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: [Smiling.] A foolish business.—Well then, in God's name, I am content.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: [Joyfully.] Art thou? Give me a kiss.

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: Robert, is this done like a brother, to snatch my good fortune from my mouth?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Devil take it. No, no, Miss, I cannot marry you.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: [Mournfully.] No! why not then?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: My brother has prior claims upon you.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Thy brother is a fool.

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: Softly, Miss. Have you not promised a hundred times to marry me? answer.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Whether it was exactly a hundred times, that Gurli does not know; but I have promised it.

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: Well, were you not upon the point of signing the contract? answer.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Indeed I was; but now I will not.

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: Brother, you have heard how matters stand.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: I have so.—No, Miss, it won't do.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p:
But I won't have him—I won't have him—I won't
have him.—Thou foolish Samuel! what hast thou to do with Gurli? Gurli will not have thee.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: It is the same thing to me; you may do as you please; but I am his brother; and, devil take me, if I can marry you.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Tell me truly and sincerely; dost thou like me?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: By my poor soul, I like you.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Then thou must marry me. Liddy, tell him so.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: A sister can only advise and intreat; she cannot command.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Who then can command him? [To Sir John.] Thou art his father; command him.

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.p: Does not Gurli know, from her own father, that parents usually, in such cases, leave children to their own wills?

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Well, then, intreat him. When my father intreats me, I then do every thing he would have me. Yes, yes, papa, intreat him, intreat him. While she is skipping about him, and stroking his cheeks, she stumbles accidentally upon his gouty foot.

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.p: [Crying out.] Oh, woe! oh woe! my leg! my leg! plague confound—oh, woe! woe!

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: [Shocked and uneasy.] Be not angry, Gurli did not do it willingly.

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.p: Help me! Liddy, help me out of this crowd. Here, there are so many people about me; and after all nothing is accomplished.—Off, off.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: [To Liddy.] Permit me to attend you.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: Willingly. [They both carry off the old man.]

div.head: SCENE VIII.
div.stage: Lady SMITH, GURLI, ROBERT, SAMUEL, JACK, STAFF, and TIDEWAITER.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: [Much vexed.] I have trode on the poor old man's sick foot. Indeed Gurli did not do it intentionally.

sp.speaker: L. Smith.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! the deno • ement of the scene amuses me not a little.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: I have never yet met with spensalia, any thing like these in the whole course of my practice.

sp.speaker: Tidewaiter.
sp.p: If other methods of thinking and of acting, are not quickly and speedily hit upon—

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: The whole matter will turn to nothing.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: [To Robert.] You have come across him, and spoilt his voyage.

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: The blood curdles in my veins. In what a labyrinth have I entangled myself by mere prudence!

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: [To Robert.] Well, saucebox, hast thou considered whether or not thou wilt marry Gurli?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: You seem to me to be a good girl. Don't you love Liddy as well as a sister?

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Yes, that Gurli does.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Then put only the case: that Liddy was desirous of marrying some honest fellow; and you carried off, without rhyme or reason, this man before her very nose—could you do so?

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Fie, Gurli could never do that.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: And yet you would have me to play such another trick to my brother—

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Dost thou then love the foolish Samuel as much as I love the good Liddy?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: [With some hesitation.] He is my loving brother.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Ah, God: that is dismal.—Gurli must cry. Weeps.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: The weather begins to grow gloomy—the sea is high.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: From what has happened, I am apt both to conclude and opine, that my office is unnecessary here at present. I hasten hence—

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: Wait, wait, Mr. Staff.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Ay, wherefore? each hour of mine must bring gold into my pockets. To-day's hinderance I shall put down to your account, and in the mean time I have the honor of recommending myself humbly to the whole company. Exit.

sp.speaker: L. Smith.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! This is then the end of the song. Th • s it happens, when noble sentiments are forgotten.

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: [After a pause] Now the question naturally occurs: what is to be done? answer: I know not.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: The sky grows clear, Sir. [Printing to the Tidewaiter, who had remained from curiosity.] But there still stands a water-spout.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Point your guns at it.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p:
[To the Tidewaiter.] My good friend, hoist your • a ••
ling, and sail out of the room.

sp.speaker: Tidewaiter.
sp.p: My good friend, be pleased to hold your tongue: I am here on the duties of my office.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Duties of your office! When did my father's house become a customhouse?

sp.speaker: Tidewaiter.
sp.p: Apprehend me right, Sir: it constitutes a part of the duties of my office, to serve and attend my worthy principal, Mr. Samuel Smith, with activity and celerity. As often as I can steal away from the customhouse, for a quarter of an hour, or even for a minute, or if it were only for a second, so often do I hasten hither with all possible precipitation.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: And now, Sir, I would intreat you to hasten hence with all precipitation.

sp.speaker: Tidewaiter.
sp.p: If I could only learn wherefore?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Because, at this very moment, I feel my fists itch and prickle, as if I had on the point of every finger, a wound just about being healed.

sp.speaker: Tidewaiter.
sp.p: Perhaps, then, you will not take it amiss, if I take my leave of you with the greatest celerity and speed.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Not at all, Sir; the more speedily, the better.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: What think you, Sir? must old Jack too lie at anchor without, and wait till you give him a signal?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: No: you may stay. [Gurli during this time had •• ood in a corner and sobbed.] What do you want, Miss.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: A husband.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Then marry my brother Samuel.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: I cannot marry him: I will have thee.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Why then only me?

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: That Gurli knows not herself. Thou art a wicked man: thou makest me weep: and yet I love thee. Look only, brother Robert, for some weeks past I have always felt as if I wanted something; and then my father said, Gurli must take a husband. Well, Gurli was very willing to do so: and then my father asked, what husband I would have? that was all one to Gurli—but since Gurli has seen thee, it is no longer all one to her.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: And hardly so to me.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Marry me, however—I will love thee more than my parrot and my kitten—I will stroke thee like my kitten, and feed thee like my parrot.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: To be fed and stroked by you, dear Gurli, is indeed no bad prospect for futurity.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Oh, we will live so happily together! thou and I, my father and my parrot, Liddy and my kitten.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Yes, yes, if only—damn it—it seems to me, as if I was not acting honorably—thy sweet prattle has sung my conscience asleep. Hark you, Gurli, can you lie?

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Lie! What is that?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Speaking otherwise than you think.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! no, that Gurli cannot do: but if it will give thee pleasure, I will learn it.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: God forbid! tell me sincerely, if brother Robert absolutely refuses to marry you, will you not then take brother Samuel.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Never! never will Gurli marry the foolish Samuel: Gurli can now no longer suffer him.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: But—but—the devil take it—it is rather knavish to supplant one's brother.—What think you, Jack? may an honest man carry off this prize with a safe conscience?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: You must know best how much water your frigate draws—but as to your brother, Sir, I would make no more ado with him, than I would with a mouldy biscuit. He struts about on the shore, indeed, with a painted bowsprit, and plenty of palaver; but I would not advise any smart wench ever to suffer him to come aboard.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: I think so too, Jack; the poor innocent wench would have a very disagreeable voyage.—Come Gurli, I'll marry you.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: [Falling about his neck.] Now thou art my dear brother Robert.—Now will Gurli laugh again, and jump and skip and dance again.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p:
Stay: now thou art my bride; and I must give you a ring. It is not, indeed, of much value, only of gold; but it signifies as much as the famous Pitt in our King's Trea
• ury. Here, take it.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: What must I make of it?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Put it on your finger—so—that is a token, that I love you.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Thou funny man; I will fetch thee also a ring, and that shall be a token of my love to thee— won't it do? She skips into her chamber.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: What think you, Jack? am I upon good anchor ground, or am I got between rocks?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: To obtain an answer to this question, you must let down the lead into your own heart.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: But is she not a smart wench? Tell me only, Jack, how the little mermaid has contrived to bring me so soon under her influence?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: I don't know: I neither stood at the helm, nor yet steered the course of the vessel.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p:
I would willingly, however, honest comrade, know
the longitude and latitude of your opinion. We Have been in so many holes and corners together, that you know me, both inside and out, as well as your own hammock—you have carried me in your arms before I was able to splice a rope; tell me, then, frankly and freely, what you think of this matter? The wench is handsome and good humoured, and has ten thousand pounds sterling.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Yes, yes, she is a neat, well built wench; understands her compass; well rigged above, and good planks below—but—

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: But! What? out with it!

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Dear heart! the wives are—such as they are—there is no bottom to be found in any of them—if I were in your place, then I would tell her—I see well how the land lies, but I'll be damn'd if I don't clear the point.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: I cannot, Jack, I have lost my tackle.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: That's bad.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: I am almost afraid, that I shall be forced to turn my keel above water.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: That is very bad—then you must go to the bottom, without one chance for your life.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: I cannot think so, Jack; I hope still to come into calm, navigable water—see only what a fine wench! She carries her soul in her eyes: and in those eyes there is no deceit. Her very heart flutters on her tongue, and her words are as fine as old wine, and as sweet as the juice of the cocoa-nut.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: But a wife is as little to be trusted as the most dangerous whirlpool upon the sea. At first it is a life full of jubilee and huzzas—but if you once sail against the stream of her inclinations, the storm immediately begins to roar, from south and north, from east and west. And then, only think, Sir; you now manage your own vessel as you please; you weigh anchor whenever you have a mind; you steer whithersoever you chuse; do you think, when you have taken a wife aboard, that your cable will be as long, and as free, as it has hitherto been?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, honest Jack: I now find that I was not in earnest when I asked your advice; for, in spite of all that you have alledged, I am resolved to tack about, and continue in the track, should I only have six points of the wind.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Then I wish you a good voyage.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Do we, at last, comrade, behold you once more? Where the devil have you been hid, since we emptied the last mug of porter at dinner together?

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: I was at the ship—I resolved never to enter this house again, and yet I am now here again, and know not myself how it has happened.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: At the ship, was you! is our crew well and hearty?

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: Only too hearty—their mirth drove me out again, for I could not be merry with them.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: How can you ask? See, Robert, it is a folly to tell it.—I went into my cabin, and lay down in my hammock, and looked up to the roof, as I had been accustomed to do during our voyage, every morning when I awaked. There the rope, with which the hammock is fastened to the • oof—but you must not laugh at me.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: No, no—only go on.

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: Well, the loop of the rope had formed an L; it looks just like an L.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Ay, ay! love is able to make the whole alphabet out of it.

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: Whenever I awaked in the morning, and looked up • o this L, then I was delighted; my thoughts ranged farther than my eyes, and this L kept me many an hour in bed.— Alas! to day, for the first time, this L drove me out of it.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Poor youth! what think you, Jack? can we not help him?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: He is deeply laden—he must throw his love over-board, else he will sink.

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: Dear Robert, will you weigh anchor soon again?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: You fool! I have not yet unloaded; and then I must first look for another cargo.

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: How long may all that take?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Six weeks at least.

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: Six weeks! ah! Robert! the poor Fazir will be dead long before that.—Why did no • I stay in my own country? I should then have died along with my brothers—here I must die alone. There some good souls would have wept over me—but here nobody will weep for me at all.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Young man, you make my heart feeble. If it can comfort you—Liddy, to all appearance, marries a very brave fellow.

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: That indeed ought to comfort me—but it comforts me not. I am brave too, am I not?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: But not rich.

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: Fie, Robert, have I not often heard you say, that honesty is better than riches?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: To be sure it is; and yet honesty gets nothing but the bones to gnaw, which pampered riches throw under the table.

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p:
And what though? It seems to me that I never could have wanted at Liddy's side. Do you recollect the poor negro, as we were once walking together in Jamaica? He was at work upon a sugar plantation; the sweat ran down his forehead; a pitcher of water stood by him, and yet he sang cheerily a Moorish song. My good friend, said you to him, this is a hard piece of work. That it is, gave he for answer, and wiped off the sweat with the palm of his hand. One question produced another. We asked him, how he was able to smile so contentedly at his hard fortune? He then pointed to a thicket a few paces off; under the thicket sat a black woman, with three little, half naked children, the youngest of whom was upon her breast. And while the negro was pointing with his finger, he looked so delighted with
himself—no—such another smile never adorned the countenance of a king. Ah! if Liddy had but been willing, Fazir would have laboured like that slave—and smiled like him.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: [Whose heart is quite melted.] Come, come, we will empty a couple of bottles of wine together.

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: I cannot.—I can neither eat nor drink—I will starve myself.

div.head: SCENE XII.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: [With a diamond ring in her hand.] Well, here I am. She perceives Fazir, stands petrified, and looks him in the face without speaking.

p.stage: Starts back at the sight of her, and in his wild eyes fixed upon her, both terror and astonishment are painted.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: What! has a thunderbolt transfixed you both?

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: [Trembling.] Brother Robert, dost thou see any thing yonder?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Yes, truly.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Dost thou really see it?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Surely I do—I am not blind.

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: Robert, do you see the spirit?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: I see a fool, and you are he.

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: Dear Robert, that body once belonged to my sister Gurli; ask it, will you, what soul has entered into it, since her death.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Your sister!

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Robert, that spirit was once called Fazir, and was my brother—ah! my dear brother!

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: I understand.—Children, keep your five senses together! First such a fright, and now such an extacy! ye are not spirits. Children, I beseech you, be not foolish! Embrace one another! Brother Fazir and sister Gurli.

sp.speaker: Fazir and Gurli.
sp.p: [At once.] Not spirits! Approaching to each other with outstretched arms.

sp.speaker: Gurli. & Fazir.
sp.p: Do you really live, Gurli?
Dost thou live, my Fazir?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: [Much affected.] What think you, Jack?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: [Wiping a tear from his eye.] Land! land!

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Right, Jack! Never did I feel so, when I unexpectedly beheld land, after a long and dangerous voyage.

sp.speaker: Fazir. and Gurli.
sp.p: [Suddenly passing into extravagant joy.] He lives! she lives! sister Gurli! brother Fazir!

div.stage: [Here the poet can prescribe nothing to the player: they skip, dance, leap, sing, laugh, and weep alternately.—Joy is always difficult to imitate; but more especially the joy of uncorrupted nature. Robert and Jack stand by, enjoying in silence the delightful spectacle.]

div.head: SCENE XIII.
div.stage: MUSAFFERY, GURLI, FAZIR, ROBERT, and JACK.

sp.speaker: Musaffery.
sp.p: I hear thy voice, Gurli—but—what—

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: Musaffery too.

sp.speaker: Musaffery.
sp.p: Fazir! thou livest! [Pressing him passionately to his breast.] How is it with me? where am I? my old brain —yes, yes, he lives!— [Beside himself with rapture.] We will celebrate a pongol! we will boil rice with milk! [Raising his hands aloft, and bowing himself thrice to the ground.] Praised be Brama! praised be Brama! Where is my master? where is Kaberdar? We will paint a cow's horns—we will crown her with a garland of flowers.

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: Kaberdar! what does he say?—Gurli, does my father too live?

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Hale and hearty! hale and hearty! Father! father!

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: [Beside himself.] Where? where? father! father!

div.head: SCENE XIV.
div.stage: Lady SMITH, KABERDAR, Sir JOHN, brought out by SAMUEL: MUSAFFERY, GURLI, FAZIR, ROBERT, and JACK.

sp.speaker: L. Smith.
sp.p: [Entering.] Ciel! what a rude plebeian tumult!

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: [Perceiving his son.] Oh God! what is this?

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: [Embracing his knees.] My father!

sp.speaker: Gurli. and Musaffery.
sp.p: [Skipping around him.] He lives, he lives!

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: [Embracing his son passionately.] Thou livest! Oh, Brama! canst thou forgive all my doubts and murmurs? my first born son lives—I have him in my arms! I have again my son! What is the wealth or the diadem of royalty, in comparison of this moment?

sp.speaker: Musaffery.
sp.p: [Bowing himself almost to the ground.] We thank thee, Brama! we thank thee!

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: [Raising his hands and eyes to Heaven.] Yes, we thank thee in silent prayer.

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.p: A sweet, delicious moment! A sovereign cordial for disease and pain.

sp.speaker: L. Smith.
sp.p: A romance! a true romance!

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: So it appears to me too.—I am yet very doubtful of its truth.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Give yourself no trouble, brother, I'll vouch for it.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: Speak, my son! By what miracle didst thou escape from our murderers?

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: I wandered about a long while, but a good angel conducted my steps. I knew not whither I went, nor what was to become of me. I was pursued every where without knowing it; and, without knowing it, every where I escaped.—Brama preserved me.

sp.speaker: Musaffery.
sp.p: [Bowing himself.] Praised be Brama!

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p:
On the tenth day of my flight, when hunger and fatigue had almost overcome me, I mounted a hill with great difficulty, and suddenly the boundless ocean lay before my sight. A foreign vessel had just sailed, and was scarcely a canon-shot from the shore. Ah! thought I, had I only arrived an hour sooner, this ship would have taken me up, and at once delivered me from all danger. I hastily untied my turban, and made the muslin flutter in the air, and beckoned and cried as loud as I could, but in vain: the ship sailed away with a fresh wind. I was almost in despair; and hunger drove me along the untrodden path, where I had hitherto
wandered, down to the shore. There I was carelessly looking for cockles, indifferent whether I was discovered or not; when, all of a sudden, with what pleasure I beheld, behind the point of a rock, another ship lying at anchor; whose captain was this generous man [Pointing to Robert.] to whom I owe my deliverance and my life, and my preservation till this moment.

sp.speaker: Musaffery.
sp.p: [Bowing himself.] Praised be Brama!

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: [Running up to Robert, and falling about his neck.] Oh, thou good man!

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Pshaw!

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: [Shaking Robert's hand.] Sir, when once you become a father, then will you feel, that for such a benefit, the gratitude of a father has no words.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: By God, Sir, you make me ashamed. When I took up the young man, I thought neither of gratitude nor reward. I obeyed my heart, and see now, I have preserved a friend to myself.

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.p: Embrace me, my son! May God bless you.

sp.speaker: L. Smith.
sp.p: ]Reaching out her hand to kiss.] Mon Fils, thy noble way of thinking, has, I assure you, quite enchanted me.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Dear mother! my way of thinking was, at that moment, so far from noble, that I was even afraid that there ran through it, a stream of envy and jealousy concealed. Three unhappy fugitives had, the evening before, also taken refuge in the ship which lay at anchor beside me; and by my poor soul, I was vexed that chance had carried them aboard of my neighbour.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: These three fugitives were we. That generous man saved the father, the daughter, and the friend; and this generous man has restored me my son.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Well, father, may not Gurli marry this good, man?

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: If he will have you, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: If he will have me! oh! yes, he will—is it not so▪ good Robert?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p:
[To Samuel.] Brother, you must not take it amiss
of me; my generous resignation would not avail you; for even then she would not take you.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: No, no, indeed, foolish Samuel; Gurli will never marry thee.

sp.speaker: Samuel.
sp.p: The question naturally occurs here: what will Mr. Samuel Smith do? answer: hang himself—if prudence would permit him:—who knows but as fair a felicity may yet bloom for him elsewhere Exit.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: Every thing seems united to prove to me, that I gained nothing when the hand of chance bound a diadem around my brow; and that I lost nothing when it was torn away.—Good children, and tried friends, what is wanting to my felicity? A good wife—and that also I have found.— Madam, your consent is now only wanting: I love your daughter Liddy. I know indeed your principles, and your respect for ancient families; but I hope to satisfy all your demands, when I assure you, that I was once monarch of Mysore, and that my ancestors bore arms with honor at the time when Alexander desolated India.

sp.speaker: L. Smith.
sp.p: I am astonished!—A family so ancient! I shall reckon it a great honor, Sir, to receive you, with open arms, into our's.

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: Ah! father!

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: Ah! dear father!

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: What's the matter, my dear son?

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: You have given me life, and would you now take it from me?

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: I love Liddy so much—

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: So! and Liddy—

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: I can neither rest night nor day.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p:
Hark you, dear youth, this is a matter which Liddy herself can alone determine.—You indeed are scarce twenty; and the freshness of youth blooms upon your cheek. I, on the other hand, carry the burden of five and thirty years upon my back.—However, so far as I know Liddy,
this will scarcely influence her decision. Let us see, we will call her. If her heart declares in your favor, I will then cheerfully submit to my fate.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Be stir yourself, Jack, and weigh anchor, and steer towards Liddy's chamber; and tell her, we in treat her to direct her course hither.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: That I will. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Father, I will tell thee, which of you two Liddy will marry.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: My brother Fazir.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: How know you that?

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: He is handsomer than thee.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: Ah! dear girl! Liddy is not a child like you.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: I fear, that in regard to this point, women will always continue children.

sp.speaker: S. John.
sp.p: Be it as it will, I shall still, before my death, have the pleasure of seeing two happy pairs.

sp.speaker: L. Smith.
sp.p: Right, my dear: this day has reconciled me again to fortune, and I shall lay myself down softly to slumber with my ancestors. Samuel's fate alone gives me uneasiness.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: The poor foolish Samuel: I am sorry for him too. —What thinkest thou, Robert? I will marry him too.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Two husbands at once! no Gurli, that I forbid.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: Well, as thou wilt: Gurli is very indifferent about it.

div.head: SCENE XV.
div.stage: LIDDY, JACK, LADY SMITH, KABERDAR, SIR JOHN, MUSAFFERY GURLI, FAZIR, and ROBERT.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Hey day, sister! I wish you joy! you are a bride.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: [Looking down.] Yes, I am a bride.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: But with whom? that is still the question.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: With whom! with that gentleman.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Hold, hold! not so hasty.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: Miss, I now release you from your promise.— Father and son stand here before you.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: [In astonishment.] Father and son!

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: Yes, this youth is my son.—He loves you—I love you too.—Make your choice freely.

sp.speaker: Gurli.
sp.p: [To Liddy.] Take the son; he is handsomer than the father.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: Your heart must pronounce the sentence.

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: [In great perplexity.] My heart! alas!

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: [With downcast eyes.] Dear Miss!

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Well, sister, will you not decide?

sp.speaker: Liddy.
sp.p: How can I? I have already given my promise.

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: If you had not then given your promise, would you not? [Liddy is silent.] I understand you. [Puts her hand into Fazir's.] God bless you, my children!

sp.speaker: Fazir.
sp.p: [Embracing Liddy.] Ah, dear Miss!

sp.speaker: Musaffery.
sp.p: [Bowing to the ground.] Praised be Brama!

sp.speaker: Kaberdar.
sp.p: [Wiping a tear from his eyes.] One single drop of bitterness! quite right: the cup of pleasure was too sweet.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Well, Jack, what think you now?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: I think that I shall now be obliged to cruise about the world by myself, with this old ruinous vessel. All my powder and lead is spent; my provisions are exhausted; and what will become of me?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: You shall stay with me; and so long as I have a biscuit to myself, I shall always make you welcome to the half of it, till you finish your voyage happily at last, and cast anchor in the latitude of Heaven.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir, I thank you: and I wish all of you, fair wind and weather for your voyage.
